context: [7] Therefore, the final outcome of NO-mediated effects would be determined by many factors including the local concentration and sources of nitric oxide and the presence of reactive molecules that might redirect the redox status in the tumor cell. [1] In the human ovarian carcinoma AD10 cell line stimulated with the pro-inflammatory cytokine IFN-Î³, we observed a markedly increased sensitivity of these tumor cells to the cytotoxic effect of TNF-Î±. [2] IFN-Î³ also induces iNOS expression in these cells . [3] Sensitization to TNF-Î± was antagonized by the use of the specific NOS inhibitorl-NMA and was mimicked by the use of the NO donor SNAP, confirming the role of nitric oxide in the sensitization process (Fig.1). [4] Frequently, IFN-Î³ treatment alone might not be sufficient to induce iNOS expression in cultured cells. [5] The participation of IFN-Î³ in the induction of iNOS is generally directed to the potentiation of the activity of pro-inflammatory cytokines like TNF-Î±, interleukin-1, or bacterial lipopolysaccharide. [6] These cytokines and/or the bacterial lipopolysaccharide have been shown to activate the transcription factor NF-ÎºB, setting the basal threshold for the induction of the expression of iNOS that might be enhanced by the action of IFN-Î³ .

llm_generation.summary: In this context, nitric oxide (NO) is implicated in the sensitization process of tumor cells to the cytotoxic effects of TNF-α, particularly in the presence of the pro-inflammatory cytokine IFN-γ. The relationship highlights how NO mediates cellular responses and influences various biological processes, including the induction of iNOS and the activation of transcription factors like NF-κB, which are crucial for inflammatory responses and tumor cell sensitivity.

The context provides a clear understanding of how NO is involved in these biological processes.
